text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

This is a new IRM speciﬁcally for managers and systems analysts in the Automated Collection Systems (ACS) program. Some content was incorporated from IRM 1.4.20, Resource Guide for Managers, Filing and Payment Compliance (F&PC) Managers Handbook and 1.4.21, Resource Guide for Managers, Accounts Management and Compliance Guide for System Administrators/Analysts. This IRM provides detailed instructions more speciﬁc to ACS employees. provides the ability for ACS employees to respond to SERP feedback more efficiently and update guidelines without reliance on third parties.

This is a new IRM speciﬁcally for managers and systems analysts in the Automated Collection Systems (ACS) program. Some content was incorporated from IRM 1.4.20, Resource Guide for Managers, Filing and Payment Compliance (F&PC) Managers Handbook and 1.4.21, Resource
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

Content has been incorporated from IRM 1.4.20, Organization, Finance and Management, Resource Guide for Managers, Filing and Payment Compliance (F&PC) managers Handbook and 1.4.21, Resource Guide for Managers-Accounts Management and Compliance Guide for Systems Administrators/Analysts
Collection System Guide for Managers and Analysts

) Overview: This IRM provides guidance on process and procedures for managing systems related to answering taxpayer telephone calls in and ance. It provides general operational objectives, various techniques, and guidelines for managing the call center. The IRM should be used in junction with other guidelines provided by call center management and the business operating division (BOD), and the Joint Operations Center and is not intended to circumvent established lines of authority. this IRM is not intended to supersede negotiated agreements. Some tions are directed to a speciﬁc operation identiﬁed in the subsection title. (
) Purpose: Management and the telephone system staff (TSS) works with BOD and JOC to effectively manage the call center systems and staffing. (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are Management and the system administrators and analysts in the call sites and the BOD analysts. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Inventory Delivery and Selection (
) Program Owner: Director, Collection Inventory Delivery and Selection Automated Collection System, Systems and Inventory (ACSSI). (
) Primary Stakeholders: ACS. (

) Program Goals: This IRM will provide guidance for managers, telephone system administrators and analysts to effectively manage the call center systems and staff to meet the business goals of the organization (

) This IRM section outlines the expectations and duties of an ACS manager based on their level in management. For the telephone system staff, the section outlines their duties with system maintenance, site telephone schedules, monitoring of telephone staff delivery and consultation with agement on telephone staffing issues. managing systems related to answering taxpayer telephone calls in Compli- ance. It provides general operational objectives, various techniques, methods, and guidelines for managing the call center. The IRM should be used in con- junction with other guidelines provided by call center management and staff, the business operating division (BOD), and the Joint Operations Center (JOC) and is not intended to circumvent established lines of authority. Additionally, this IRM is not intended to supersede negotiated agreements. Some subsec- tions are directed to a speciﬁc operation identiﬁed in the subsection title.

) This section will outline the roles and responsibilities for Automated System (ACS) managerial staff and telephone system staff. There will be speciﬁc IRM sections to outline these different responsibilities for these The manager section will provide guidance for all levels of management in ACS. The telephone system staff section will provide guidance for all within a System Support team. (

) The following reports assist with management controls: • Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS) Reports • National Quality Review System (NQRS) Reports • Accounts Management Services (AMS) Reports • Overage Report Compiler and Sorter (ORCAS) • ACS Reports • Monthly Monitoring Report (MMR) • Work Planning and Control (WP&C) Reports • Case Control Activity System (CCA) Report • Collection Activity Report (CAR) (

) Program objectives for phones are compiled by the JOC and reported on JOC Web page. These reports are frequently reviewed and discussed at various levels of the organization, including BOD directors, BOD analysts, site management. (
) Program Effectiveness: Program goals are measured against guidelines contained in the BOD program letters and established BOD business measures for each ﬁscal year. (
) Restructuring & Reform Act of
(RRA
), Section

, prohibits the of records of tax enforcement results to evaluate employees, impose or suggest production quotas or goals with respect to such employees. This applies to all employees regardless of position held or location in which the work is performed. For purpose of implementing this section, IRM
, IRS Balanced Measurement System, refers to employees exercising in determining tax liability or ability to pay as “Section
Employees.” (

oint site • BOD annual program letter provided on each BOD Web site: the gram letter provides speciﬁc guidelines, goals and strategies used to ensure consistent telephone and inventory program delivery and assistance and guidance to the sites as they create their strategic operational goals • Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) covering Customer Service erations between Internal Revenue Service and National Treasury ployees Union (NTEU), also known as the Customer Service (CSA): the CSA applies to all bargaining unit employees assigned to campus and remote sites and is intended to enhance taxpayer and business efficiency by taking full advantage of changes in ogy, while at the same time promoting employee satisfaction • Vendor-provided user guides for telephone-related systems (
) The work priority and selection process is designed to ensure that cases selected with integrity and fairness. and (

) Work priority generally falls into two categories; immediate (customers in) and delayed (inventory processing) demand. Cases in the immediate demand category have the same priority for selection whereas inventory selection uses a priority scheme. (
) Work selection is based on a combination of factors such as case priority, current organizational program needs, and available staff. Case selection generally occurs as shown below. (

) Systemic Processes: a. FERDI and Non-FERDI /FPLP – no limits are placed on these processes. b. ACS systemic levies and letters – limited as part of the phone forecast prepared by the SB/SE HQ Collection Joint Operations (JOC) liaison staff. (

ACS Call Site or Operations Managers: Provide general oversight to approvals are done promptly. ACS Call Site Team Managers: should take the following actions on a daily basis: • Address your own employee’s cases requiring approval and ensure employees are making case prints when approvals are required or a query/listing process is used. • Address cases remaining in the zero functions by working through the managerial approval inventory assigned to your team using next case access. If the work is correct, approve the case or if it can be resolved with a simple input, that action should be taken without referring the account • Address work done by another Call Site employee that is not correct and/or cannot be resolved by providing your Call Site’s ACS approval process contact person with the TIN, the employee ID, and date moved to the managerial function (or Screen

print). The tion will be forwarded daily to the Call Site of the employee taking the case action for appropriate follow-up. Please DO NOT forward cases that you can correct easily. ACS Employee’s Responsibility: With nationwide call routing (Enterprise) ,

) Inform the other ACS Call Sites of cases in your site’s managerial approval inventories that require additional attention prior to closure via fax promptly. Your site’s team leaders will provide this information. Promptly resolve or cases identiﬁed by other Sites as needing additional work to the appropriate team manager for follow-up. To ensure that information is properly verify that the fax was sent successfully. The contact person will enter AMS comments on cases (both the person sending the account and the person sponding in the originating site) to clearly record actions taken. (

1.4 Resource Guide for Managers

) If the referred account has not been resolved after two attempts, contact the managerial approval fax contact person in the receiving site by phone or secure e-mail (if the site accepts this type of transmission) to resolve the standing issue promptly. Local practice will be followed to elevate the issue if the account remains unresolved after that contact. (

) The role and responsibilities of a system administrator (analyst) are as • Ensuring system is properly conﬁgured to meet organizational and Analysts erational objectives; • Maintaining a trouble log to monitor response time problems, circuit problems, unusual staffing situations (snow days, building closures, or any other factor which could distort telephone data and affect or staffing plans; • Ensuring circuitry meets standardization requirements; • Adhering to schedule; • Checking the Automated Collection System/Integrated Collection System (ACS/ICS) Parameter File for the correct date and cycle; • Reviewing the reports that are generated from the system to if the operation is achieving its goal and identify system problems that may exist within the system; • Distributing ACS/ICS and QMF Reports to appropriate managerial levels, providing assistance to managers and employees, and user proﬁles and assigning passwords; • Checking voice disk space; • Printing and reviewing Telephone Routing Interactive Systems ment Information Statistics (TRIS MIS); • Monitoring agents for long wrap and idle times as needed; • Analyzing systems impact resulting from Headquarter office mainte- nance, TRIS Project Office Master Customer Service Script changes, etc.; • Advising Operation management and facilitate implementation with involved parties; • Instructing site employees on new features and procedures and shoot system and equipment problems resulting from changes; • Creating QMF and Aceyus reports as requested by the Operation Manager. (

) Each site should have Query Master File (QMF) extracts to allow for a complete picture of the status of inventories in the site. Those extracts be requested as needed or on a regular basis and be reviewed by the priate level of management to look for possible inventory issues or (
) Systems Analysts have the ability to create, modify and run extracts (

) Extracts should be reviewed for various reasons, including but not limited to: • Age of the inventory related to past follow-up dates in each inventory, • Inventory levels in conjunction with priority case deﬁnitions, • Closures and new inventory receipts on a weekly basis. (
) Operation management should identify inventories beyond the time-frames

standing issue promptly. Local practice will be followed to elevate the issue if the account remains unresolved after that contact.

(1) The ACSWeb National Office Menu consists of the following tables: Menu Title of Table Description of Table Levy Source Priority Table (PL00) Table allows user to add different types of levy source documents by completing various ﬁelds. Use guidelines in IRM 5.19.4, En- forcement Action, to input valid sources Batch Action Request (BA00) Table is used by Analysts to sys- temically close cases based on various criteria and obvious results National Inventory (NI00) Table displays Inventories assigned to various sites Parameter File Maintenance Table is used by Analysts to set (PM00) up various systemic actions from the ACS database such as issuing letters or levies Restriction by Proﬁle (RS00) Table is used by Analysts to restrict access to various invento- ries by ACS proﬁle Business Priority (BP00) Table lists inventories by business priority and Consolidated Decision Analytics (CDA) score Levy Source Deletion (LD00) Table is used by Analyst to sys- temically delete levy sources by batch Disaster Assignment Table Table is used by Analysts to set (DA00) up systemic letter issuance for disaster cases Special Inventory Assignment Table is used by Analyst to set up (SI00) various inventories for distribution to speciﬁc sites National Site Table (NS00) Table is used by Analyst to change or add call site informa- tion Levy Source Block (LB00) Table lists levy sources that are blocked from being added to the ACS database example: State Refunds
The ACSWeb National Office Menu consists of the following tables:

) The ACS security system exists in the appropriate campus and is used control access to the ACS host system. To add or remove users from File system the following steps must take place: a. The ACS employee must complete an online Form

request. are routed through the appropriate channels for management and then routed to the security office at the campus. The security issues a RACF user number for all new employees. b. Following issuance of the RACF user number, the ACS systems will create a temporary RACF password. c. The RACF user member is entered on the ACS Security Screen (SMOO) with the appropriate team, function and unit. (

) This process is utilized to specify that a user is to be allowed access to system again. The analyst would normally use RESUME to restore a access to the system that has been revoked by: • Three consecutive unsuccessful password/log in attempts • A prior REVOKE command (
) You can assign a new entry password and RESUME the proﬁle at any See Exhibit

detailed instructions. Always remember to do the following: • DISPLAY the user before resuming that user. See Exhibit detailed instructions. • Verify the appropriate action is taken on the correct user. (

) When an employees proﬁle is “REVOKED”, this speciﬁes that RACF is prevent a user from accessing the system. The users proﬁle and DATA are not deleted. The user cannot access the system, and the employee denied access at their next log in attempt. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
The ACS employee must complete an online Form

request. These are routed through the appropriate channels for management approval and then routed to the security office at the campus. The security office issues a RACF user number for all new employees. Following issuance of the RACF user number, the ACS systems analyst will create a temporary RACF password. The RACF user member is entered on the ACS Security Maintenance Screen (SMOO) with the appropriate team, function and unit.

When an employees proﬁle is “REVOKED”, this speciﬁes that RACF is to prevent a user from accessing the system. The users proﬁle and DATA SETS are not deleted. The user cannot access the system, and the employee will denied access at their next log in attempt.

) A user should always be “REVOKED” if detailed to another position for
days or more. (
) If a user no longer needs ACS/ICS access DELETE the user by completing OL

for detailed instructions. (

) The ACS application is subject to Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) and Cybersecurity guidelines which requires annual testing of application to ensure security guidelines are maintained. In addition, annual disaster recovery testing is completed to ensure the system can be should a disaster occur. ACS HQ participates in theses annual tests on of the business to provide evidence of compliance to security requirements (
) The ACS application is two tiered which requires user to have a valid RACF ID, ACS User ID and a password to access. The ACS application has a systemic process to inactive RACF IDs after
days of inactivity then delete them after

days. ACS HQ receives daily reports of users meeting the deleted criteria then inactivates the ACS ID on these accounts. ACS HQ notiﬁes the site SA staffs weekly of the accounts that have been deleted. In addition, since ACS also provides access to external customers such as TAC offices and TAS, ACS HQ also deletes these accounts based on the daily reports and notiﬁes the areas. (

) The process of granting access to the ACS system uses a multi-step process. This ensures that only users who have a business need to obtain access to the ACS system are granted the correct permissions. To protect system integrity and taxpayer information the Online

process has three levels of approval at the site. The ﬁrst level is for the employee to request access, the second level is for manager approval, and the third level is for system office SA approval. This process was setup to conform to FISMA and Cybersecurity procedures which operate under three primary principles • Separation of duties – separate levels to ensure that the request for access are reviewed by more than one person. • Least Privileged Access – employees should be granted the lowest of permission necessary to perform their required duties. • Accountability – audit trails that ensure that Agency has taken steps to protect taxpayer information from unauthorized access. (

) System’s management begins with the establishment of the Security for IDRS, ACS and the Resource Allocation Control File (RACF). Information input to the Security database authorizes employees to use the system and keeps track of employee information for reporting purposes. Information input to the Security database authorizes employees to use the system and keeps track of employee information for reporting purposes. (

This process was setup to conform to FISMA and Cybersecurity procedures which operate under three primary principles • Separation of duties – separate levels to ensure that the request for access are reviewed by more than one person.

System’s management begins with the establishment of the Security database for IDRS, ACS and the Resource Allocation Control File (RACF). Information input to the Security database authorizes employees to use the system and keeps track of employee information for reporting purposes.
System Guide for Managers and

) For security purposes, perform the following tasks: • Prepare written instructions to users and conduct training to overall system security; • Maintain a current and historical master record of all control ACS, and IDRS users within the call-site; • Maintain a complete listing of all call site hardware; • Maintain system-wide records concerning security on the parameter • Perform periodic reviews of IDRS command code proﬁles with managers to ensure that employees have only those command that are required to complete the job; • Assure that proﬁle change requests are appropriate and meet criteria; • Monitor security reports; • Ensure that RACF and IDRS security violations are identiﬁed and propriate remedial actions are taken • Inform the operation of continuing violations and provide appropriate documentation • Maintain appropriate records of security violations. (

) Call Center SAs are required to perform quarterly certiﬁcation of active users. These reviews protect the integrity of the ACS system by ensuring only authorized users have access. This is action required for all ACS regardless of the number of proﬁles. After the review, a signed quarterly cation document must be submitted to HQ no later than
days after the of the quarter. (

) Telephone Systems Analysts (TSA) can use the Query Management (QMF for Windows) desktop application to query for information and create reports for ACS. QMF offers multiple interfaces, (build, prompted, or SQL) help users build queries based on their skill level. TSAs can query most in the ACS database for open and closed cases. An ACS data dictionary provides the deﬁnitions of each ﬁeld and can be used to assist with queries. The ACS Data Dictionary is stored on the ACSSI Systems Analyst (SA) Shar

oint site. Note: For account related queries/reports, the ACS Case Reference Number (CRN) should be used in lieu of the TIN. The CRN allows users to taxpayer accounts assigned to ACS and was created to protect the of taxpayers’ accounts. (
) TSAs will automatically have access to QMF through the approval of the OL
“PROD SA (SRP) ‘site’ ACS ”application (where ‘site’ is the call location). Upon approval, TSAs shall submit an OS Ge

ervices ticket for install QMF for Windows. After QMF has been installed, users will need to import an “*.ini ”ﬁle to conﬁgure QMF. Job aids and training material are located on the ACSSI Customer Shar
oint. The site contains instructions importing the “*.ini” ﬁle, conﬁgure QMF, and creating personal workspace.
Automated Collection System Guide for Managers and Systems Analysts 1.4.61

propriate remedial actions are taken Inform the operation of continuing violations and provide appropriate documentation Maintain appropriate records of security violations.
) TSAs will automatically have access to QMF through the approval of the OL

ervices ticket for IT to install QMF for Windows. After QMF has been installed, users will need to import an “*.ini ”ﬁle to conﬁgure QMF. Job aids and training material are located on the ACSSI Customer Shar

To assist TSAs with site operations, the ACSSI group creates and uploads queries to the SA SharePoint site. These queries include:

ACS ACCESS – displays list of Active users on the ACS system APPROVAL – Approval cases sent by the site’s employees that needs to be worked APPROVAL AGED – Site approval inventory that will be aged at the end of the week CASES WORKED BY _EMPLOYEE – Cases worked by Operators (O proﬁle) not signed into I
CASES WORKED BY SITE – Count of cases worked by Operators (O proﬁle) not signed into I
(incoming calls)

The ACS work planning process begins with labor review resource funding estimates provided by the Finance Office. Finance builds their analysis on: a. Current staff on
rolls counts as of certain pay
periods b. Expected future hiring c. Projected attrition and unpaid leave factors Once Finance provides these resource needs estimates in terms of Full

Time Equivalent funding (FTE), Collection Planning and Performance Analysis (PPA), works with ACS Headquarters, JOC and Campus Collection to assumptions and set ACS Enterprise level targets for the upcoming ﬁscal Assumptions and targets are established at the ACS Enterprise level based history and known changes that will affect business results and include: a. Direct time – expressed as a percentage of total time ACS expends on taxpayer service and supporting activities b. Phone time – expressed as a percentage of total time ACS expends handling taxpayer phone calls c. Telephone level
of

service (LOS) – the percent of total calls ACS to answer based on JOC projected call volumes for the upcoming year, total ACS FTE and projected phone hours d. Balance Due (TDA) and Return Delinquency (TDI) case closures e. Customer Accuracy – expectations are based on past National Quality Review Service (NQRS) results ACS work plan resources are allocated to three planning periods; October – December, January – June, and July – September.
The ACS work planning process begins with labor review resource funding estimates provided by the Finance Office. Finance builds their analysis on:
Assumptions and targets are established at the ACS Enterprise level based on history and known changes that will affect business results and include:

a. Direct time – expressed as a percentage of total time ACS expends on taxpayer service and supporting activities b. Phone time – expressed as a percentage of total time ACS expends handling taxpayer phone calls c. Telephone level
of

service (LOS) – the percent of total calls ACS expects to answer based on JOC projected call volumes for the upcoming year, total ACS FTE and projected phone hours d. Balance Due (TDA) and Return Delinquency (TDI) case closures e. Customer Accuracy – expectations are based on past National Quality Review Service (NQRS) results
ACS work plan resources are allocated to three planning periods; October December, January – June, and July – September.
1.4 Resource Guide for Managers
) While work plan resources are allocated to the ACS sites based on each staff levels, most work-plan targets remain at the Enterprise level. (
) Campus Collection staff and Directors may choose to set Directorate level targets such as a direct time target based on the ACS Enterprise level (
) ACS Headquarters monitors proper function and program usage as well ACS performance against plan and periodically make recommendations Campus Collection and the ACS sites based on their analysis. (
) More information about the overall Campus Collection Work Plan Process contained in IRM
, Work Plans and Staffing. (
) Follow IRM
, Quality for guidelines on the Quality Measurement Process, Role of Centralized Quality Review (CQRS) and Program System Reviewer (PAS), EQRS/NQRS Standard Reports and Role of the Campus Analyst. (
) Follow IRM
, Training and Employee Development for guidance Core Training, ACS Interactive Training, On the Job Training and Training All Employees.
While work plan resources are allocated to the ACS sites based on each site’s staff levels, most work-plan targets remain at the Enterprise level.
Campus Collection staff and Directors may choose to set Directorate level targets such as a direct time target based on the ACS Enterprise level

Note: If your screen looks like this (see Example below) before you hit your ﬁnal Control you are
TFU, mm T = Team, F = Function, U = Unit, m
m = an eight

digit employee number; designation. Used by a manager to call up all cases worked by this employee the current date while signed on in the particular function/unit designated. Employees’s work will be sequenced and displayed on the terminal in the order it was processed. If m

m is not entered, the system will list all work performed by the designated function/unit in employee number order. ACS validates that requester is in unit. TFU, Same as ER except prints a hard copy listing at the call site overnight. Used to view alphabetical listing of employees with employee numbers entered on XX = team/function. Used to view the daily real time inventory report by team, function and unit. Displays Daily Workload Report by team for this call site. ACS validates that requester is in the unit. Used to access the Management Report Query Menu Used to display the Security Maintenance screen and maintain security information on employees in their team within the same function.

ACS applications were created for each call site and/or support sites with separate applications for each RACF proﬁles. In addition, applications were created for TAC offices based on region, Lions World Service clients and HQ applications for Analysts and Quality. The RACF proﬁles are as follows:
